response.answer_text: Question: “Is deoxyribose a carbohydrate?” Answer: Yes. Scold: Seriously, all I had to do was put the word “deoxyribose” into the search tab for google and it came up with seven immediate responses that said that this is a sugar, that it is a carbohydrate, and much much more. One was a dictionary (these exist on paper too), one was a wikipedia page, one was a biology dictionary, one was a school science learning site, and one was the Encyclopedia Britannica, and that was all in just the first few pages.Why would you ask this here instead of using a search engine?
Yes. Because it is a deoxy sugar it does not exactly match the common generic formula of monosachharides, CHO, but it is still regarded as a carbohydrate.

Carbohydrates - Ribose. Ribose and its related compound, deoxyribose, are the building blocks of the backbone chains in nucleic acids, better known as DNA and RNA. Ribose is used in RNA and deoxyriboseis used in DNA. ... Ribose and deoxyribose are classified as monosaccharides, aldoses, pentoses, and are reducing sugars.
